questions.text: Time to turn 1 parent cell into 2 daughter cells
Turning on enzymes, very little division
Number of cells dying is equal to number being made (toxic metabolites)
No more nutrients, decline in division
Helicase and topoisomerase (e.g. gyrase) separate and unwind. Quinolone drugs target gyrase.
DNA dependent RNA pol which is target for drug rifampin. Polycistronic mRNA. Coupled with translation.
70s ribosome made of 30s and 50s subunits. Target for several antimicrobial agents.
Sigma factors: bind to RNA and recognize promoter. Allows for specificity
Glucose is preferred substrate. If glucose is present, no expression of lac operon
Homologous: gene exchange process that needs homology between DNA strands. Requires recombinase A
Transposon:can move from one DNA site to another
Horizontal transfer via gene transfer mechanisms (above)
Operon: cluster of co-regulated genes. Pathogenicity island: group of genes for virulence mech under control of one promoter
May be lost without selective pressure
Internal flagella provide corkscrew motility for spirochetes
Phospholipid bilayer with proteins and porins
Two organisms interact, one benefits, other unharmed
Two organisms interact, one benefits, other harmed
When organisms is present, patient has disease
Organism causing disease under certain conditions (e.g. immunosuppression)
Person, harboring a pathogen, who is not sick but is infectious
Bacteria in the bloodstream that are causing systemic illness
Ability of organism to cause disease

Lowest concentration of drug that kills bacteria

Heating food and beverages to destroy microorganisms

Host that contains the developing parasite

Infect vascular endothelial cells → (1) induced endocytosis (2) lysis of phagosome membrane (3) replication in host cell cytoplasm (4) lysis of host cell → vascular damage (hemorrhage, edema, rash), LPS - weak endotoxin activity, vasculitis and thrombosis

Virulence plasmids: Capsule (F1 protein), plasminogen activator (prevents opsonization and platelets aggregation), Type III secretion system: Yop proteins inhibit cytokines + prevent phagocytosis, Endotoxin (septic shock)

Infects reticuloendothelial organs: multiplication in macrophages, hepatocytes and endothelial cells => necrosis and granuloma production in areas of multiplication, Survival: inhibition of phagosome-lysosome fusion, capsule
Multiply in macrophages in reticuloendothelial system => granulomas => septicemia
Antigenic variation - escape immune clearance, autoimmune activities of anti-Osp, LPS
Multiply in blood and tissues, inflammation/immune complexes → renal damage

Stage1 (localized infect.): erythema migrans (bull's eye appearance) + flu-like symptoms, Stage2 (disseminated infect.): cardiac and neurologic (nerve palsies) abnormalities, Stage3 (persistent infection): fluctuating arthritis.
Acute septicemic phase: flu-like symptoms, Immune phase: anicteric form (possible meningitis), icteric form or Weil's disease (jaundice, renal failure, subconjunctival hemorrhage)
Flu-like symptoms, night sweats, Possible enlargement of reticuloendothelial organs.
Multiple recurrent febrile episodes 5-day fever with pain in long bones and sweating, Skin lesions in bacillary angiomatosis cases
Flu-like symptoms, night sweats, Possible enlargement of reticuloendothelial organs.

Ulceroglandular form (most common): painful ulcerating lesion at site of infection, Pneumonic, Gastrointestinal & Septicemic forms (more severe), Oculoglandular form: purulent conjunctivitis + lymphadenopathy
Flu-like symptoms, Multiplication in regional lymph node => suppurative lymphadenitis
Fever, headache, malaise, myalgia. Leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, increased liver enzymes
Flu-like symptoms, gradual onset, rash on trunk
Eschar at bite site, Dissemination → flu-like symptoms + fever + generalized rash (randomly distributed)
Flu-like symptoms, petechial-hemorrhagic rash (first on extremities → spread to body, on palms/soles), various organ failures. Fever + Rash + Headache + Previous tick bite
Clinical presentation + Serologic tests (indirect immuno-fluorescence assay, immuno-staining, Weil-Felix for RMSF)
Clinical presentation + Microscopy: Giemsa (Morulae) + Serologic tests: IFA, PCR

Serologic tests, PCR, microscopy, culture requires cysteine-glucose blood agar
Clinical + CDC protocol: EIA or IFA, if positive then Western blot to confirm
Microscopy (during febrile period) Giemsa or Wright staining, Serologic tests unhelpful (because of antigenic variation)
Serologic tests, PCR, fastidious growth requirements

Catheter & prosthetic device infections - nosocomial infections

Most common cause of subacute IE (abnormal or damaged valves)
Uncommon complications of pseudomonas bacteremia , Causes IE in IV drug users and patients with prosthetic heart valves

Exotoxin A (inhibits protein synthesis), capsule, LPS

Water organisms, GNR, Facultative intracellular pathogen

questions.text: Spore (w/ calcium dipicolinate), capsule, PA + EF = edema toxin, PA + LF = lethal toxin, Inhalation of anthrax spores  germinate and replicate in alveolar macrophages Transport through pulmonary lymphatics to mediastinal lymph nodes

Spore-like stage for environmental survival, intracellular survival
Developmental cycle: EB (infectious, survives outside the host, non reproductive particles), RB (noninfectious, intracytoplasmic, reproductive form)
Capsule: no phagocytosis, Endotoxin: fever, inflammation and shock (septicemia)  necrotic destruction of alveolar spaces, abscesses
Polysaccharide capsule (major, antiphagocytic), IgA protease (colonization),Pneumolysin (transmembrane pore-forming toxin), autolysin (release of intracellular factors & cell wall)

Survival & growth in alveolar macrophages (sulfolipids, cord factor/ trehalose dimycolate): cell wall components (Mycolic acid, lipids & LAM), Development of reactive inflammatory focus Caseous tissue necrosis - damage due to host response Granuloma formation (Ghon complex, CMI, tuberculin)

Infects tracheobronchial epithelium, Immobilization of cilia: Fha (filamentous hemagglutinin) + Ptx (Pertussis toxin), Killing of ciliated cells: Tracheal cytotoxin, Increase in mucus secretion & edema: Ptx (A-B toxin, ADP-ribosylation of G-protein  adenylate cyclase activity cAMP,

Diphtheria toxin (A-B exotoxin encoded on lysogenic phage): ADP ribosylation of EF-2  blocks protein synthesis cell death necrosis , diffusion of toxin via blood  damages heart and peripheral nervous system
M-protein (adhesion & antiphagocytic), hyaluronic acid capsule (non-immunogenic),Streptolysins (pore forming), Exoenzymes
Ear pain, sinus congestion, bronchitis, pneumoniae
Pharyngitis: sore throat, fever, erythema + exudate
Sore throat, gray exudate, thick pseudomembrane obstruction and suffocation, bull neck, cardiac dysfunction, laryngeal nerve palsy
Primarily illness of resp. system - can attack any part of the body, Active TB: chronic cough,weight loss, night sweats, bloody sputum
Catarrhal stage: non specific, highly contagious, Paroxysmal stage: paroxysmal cough with inspiratory whoop, mucus production, vomiting, Convalescent stage: gradual recovery
Sudden onset, high fever, thick bloody sputum (currant jelly), especially in older males
Pneumonia or bronchitis: gradual onset of cough, malaise, little or no fever,dry cough, sequelae- atherosclerosis
Fever & chills,mental confusion, diarrhea, non-productive cough, chest pain
Fever, chills, cough, malaise, headache, rapidly worsening course of fever, edema and massive enlargement of mediastinal lymph nodes , respiratory distress, cyanosis and septicemia, death
Not seen on Gram stain, serodiagnosis by complement fixation test or microimmunofluorescnt antibody
Direct fluoroescent antibody, Culture: BCYE agar (Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract), Urinary Antigen Test

Antitoxin serum therapy + penicillin, Prevention: toxoid vaccine (DTaP, Tdap, DT, and Td)

Soil with decaying organic material - Midwest / Eastern US

Bind to host cells turn into yeast (extracellular), dissemination: multiple organs, skin (cutaneous form)
Conidia turn into yeast cells  multiplication inside macrophages, dissemination via macrophages  skin, reticuloendothelial system
Bind to host cells turn into yeast cells, dissemination: skin , mucosa, lymphoid organs…

Rhinocerebral (especially in diabetic & leukemic pts.), pulmonary, gastrointestinal, cutaneous, disseminated zygomycoses
Pulmonary infections, dissemination (meningitis in AIDS patients)

Fungus flu (acute pneumonia), chronic TB-like disease
Vally fever (flu-like), desert bumps (lesions on skin, bone, CNS)

Gradual onset (weeks), nonspecific symptoms  (headache, vomiting, fever)
